subsection.title: Impulse Forcing
subsection.p: Impulse forcingimpulse forcing is the term used to describe a very quick push or pull on a system, such as the blow of a hammer or the force of an explosion. For example, consider the equation for a damped harmonic oscillator \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + 2 \frac{dy}{dt} + 26 y = g(t), where g(t) is a function that is very large in a very short time interval, say |t - t_0| \lt \tau and zero otherwise. The integral I(\tau) = \int_{t_0 - \tau}^{t_0 + \tau} g(t) \, dt or since g(t) is zero outside of the interval |t - t_0| \lt \tau I(\tau) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(t) \, dt measures the strength or impulseimpulse of the forcing function g(t). In particular, assume that t_0 = 0 and g(t) = d_{\tau}(t) = \begin{cases} 1/ 2\tau, & -\tau \lt t \lt \tau \\ 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases} It is easy to see that I(\tau) = 1 in this case.

Examining this forcing function over shorter and shorter time intervals with \tau getting closer and closer to zero, we find that I(\tau) = 1 in all cases. Thus, \lim_{\tau \to 0} d_\tau(t) = 0 for t \neq 0; however, \lim_{\tau \to 0} I(\tau ) = 1.

We can use this information to define the unit impulse functionimpulseunit impulse function, \delta(t), to be the ``function'' that imparts an impulse of magnitude one at t = 0, but is zero for all values of t other than zero. In other words, \delta(t) has the properties
\delta(t) = 0, \qquad t \neq 0; \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t) \, dt = 1.
Of course, we study no such function in calculus. The ``function'' \delta is an example of what is known as a generalized functiongeneralized function. We call \delta, the Dirac delta functionDirac delta function.

subsection.title: The Laplace Transform of the Dirac Delta Function
subsection.p:
Even though the Dirac delta function is not a piecewise continuous, exponentially bounded function, we can define its Laplace transform as the limit of the Laplace transform of d_\tau(t) as \tau \to 0. More specifically, assume that t_0 \gt 0 and {\mathcal L}(\delta(t - t_0)) = \lim_{\tau \to 0} {\mathcal L}(d_\tau(t - t_0)). Assuming that t_0 - \tau \gt 0, the Laplace transform of d_\tau(t - t_0) is
{\mathcal L}(d_\tau(t - t_0)) & = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} d_\tau(t - t_0) \, dt & = \int_{t_0 - \tau}^{t_0 + \tau} e^{-st} d_\tau(t - t_0) \, dt & = \frac{1}{2 \tau} \int_{t_0 - \tau}^{t_0 + \tau} e^{-st} \, dt & = \frac{1}{2 s \tau} e^{-st} \bigg|_{t = t_0 - \tau}^{t = t_0 + \tau} & = \frac{1}{2 s \tau} e^{-st_0} (e^{s\tau} - e^{-s \tau}) & = \frac{\sinh s \tau}{s \tau} e^{-st_0}.
We can use l'Hospital's rule to evaluate (\sinh s \tau)/ s \tau as \tau \to 0, \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{\sinh s \tau}{s \tau} = \lim_{\tau \to 0} \frac{s \cosh s \tau}{s} = 1. Thus, {\mathcal L}(\delta(t - t_0)) = e^{-st_0}. We can extend this result to allow t_0 = 0, by \lim_{t_0 \to 0} {\mathcal L}(\delta(t - t_0)) =\lim_{t_0 \to 0} e^{-st_0} = 1.

Let us now solve the initial value problem
\frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + 2 \frac{dy}{dt} + 26 y & = \delta_4(t) y(0) & = 1 y'(0) & = 0.
We can think of this as a damped harmonic oscillator that is struck by a hammer at time t = 4. Let Y(s) = {\mathcal L}(y)(s) and take the Laplace transform of both sides of the differential equation to obtain s^2 Y(s) - sy(0) - y'(0) + 2(sY(s) - y(0)) + 26 Y(s) = {\mathcal L}(\delta_4)(s) or s^2 Y(s) - s + 2sY(s) - 2 + 26 Y(s) = e^{-4s}. Solving for Y(s), we have Y(s) = \frac{s + 2}{s^2 + 2s + 26} + \frac{e^{-4s}}{s^2 + 2s + 26}. The inverse Laplace transform of Y(s) is
y & = {\mathcal L}\left( \frac{s + 2}{s^2 + 2s + 26} \right) + {\mathcal L}\left(\frac{e^{-4s}}{s^2 + 2s + 26}\right) & = {\mathcal L}\left( \frac{s + 2}{(s+ 1)^2 + 25} \right) + \frac{1}{5} {\mathcal L}\left(\frac{5e^{-4s}}{(s + 1)^2 + 25}\right) & = e^{-t} \cos 5t + \frac{1}{5} e^{-t} \sin 5t + \frac{1}{5} u_4(t) e^{-(t - 4)} \sin(5(t-4)).
It is important to notice that we are using the Dirac delta function like an ordinary function. This requires some rigorous mathematics to justify that we can actually do this.

ul.li: Impulse forcing is the term used to describe a very quick push or pull on a system, such as the blow of a hammer or the force of an explosion. For example, consider the equation for a damped harmonic oscillator \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + p \frac{dy}{dt} + q y = g(t), where g(t) is a function that is very large in a very short time interval, say |t - t_0| \lt \tau and zero otherwise. The integral I(\tau) = \int_{t_0 - \tau}^{t_0 + \tau} g(t) \, dt or since g(t) is zero outside of the interval |t - t_0| \lt \tau I(\tau) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} g(t) \, dt measures the strength or impulse of the forcing function g(t).

We define the unit impulse function, \delta(t), to be the ``function'' that imparts an impulse of magnitude one at t = 0, but is zero for all values of t other than zero. In other words, \delta(t) has the properties
\delta(t) = 0, \qquad t \neq 0; \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t) \, dt = 1.
The function \delta is an example of what is known as a generalized function. We call \delta, the Dirac delta function.

The Laplace transform of the Dirac delta function is {\mathcal L}(\delta(t - t_0)) = e^{-st_0}. We can extend this result to allow t_0 = 0, by \lim_{t_0 \to 0} {\mathcal L}(\delta(t - t_0)) =\lim_{t_0 \to 0} e^{-st_0} = 1.

We can use the Dirac delta function to solve initial value problems such as
\frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + 2 \frac{dy}{dt} + 26 y & = \delta_4(t) y(0) & = 1 y'(0) & = 0,
or \frac{d^2y}{dt^2} + p \frac{dy}{dt} + q y = g(t), where g(t) is a function that is very large in a very short time interval.
